"Well, you see... I really don’t know how to say it right. It’s a fun idea about how people think. When you wrote your article, you must have imagined yourself a bit as an ‘extraordinary’ man, saying something new, right? Isn’t that true?"

"Maybe," Raskolnikov replied with a sneer.

Razumihin moved a little. 

"And if you faced tough times or needed to help others, would you break the rules? Like, would you steal or kill?" He winked with one eye and laughed quietly.

"If I did, I definitely wouldn’t tell you," Raskolnikov replied angrily.

"No, I was just curious because of your article, from a writing point of view..."

"Ugh! That’s so obvious and rude!" Raskolnikov thought with disgust.

"Let me say," he replied coldly, "that I don’t think of myself as a Mahomet or a Napoleon, or anyone like that. Since I’m not one of them, I can’t say how I would act."

"Oh, come on, don’t we all think we’re like Napoleons in Russia now?" Porfiry Petrovitch said with a strange familiarity. 

There was something odd in how he said it.

"Maybe it was one of these future Napoleons who killed Alyona Ivanovna last week?" Zametov suddenly said.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with the idea of whether extraordinary individuals can justify committing crimes for a greater purpose.
